contents.content: • Can understand sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of most immediate relevance (e.g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, local geography, employment).
• Can communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a1 simple and direct exchange of information on familiar and routine matters.
• Can describe in simple terms aspects of his/her background,immediate environment and matters in areas of immediate Basic need.
Welcome / Icebreaker
Let's get to know each other / one another better.

By the end of this lesson, students will be able to introduce themselves and others using be and possessive adjectives, and ask and answer Wh-questions to find out information about others and to state information about themselves.

contents.linkLabel: Flipped Classroom • Where are you from? (Cycle 1)
Classwork • Where are you from? (Cycle 1)
Homework • Where are you from? (Cycle 1)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to ask and answer yes/no questions to find out information about others and to state information about themselves.

contents.linkLabel: Flipped Classroom • Where are you from? (Cycle 2)
Classwork • Where are you from? (Cycle 2)
Homework • Where are you from? (Cycle 2)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to ask and answer questions about occupations using the simple present.

contents.linkLabel: Flipped Classroom • What do you do? (Cycle 1)
Classwork • What do you do? (Cycle 1)
Homework • What do you do? (Cycle 1)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to describe routines and daily schedules using time expressions.

contents.linkLabel: Flipped Classroom • What do you do? (Cycle 2)
Classwork • What do you do? (Cycle 2)
Homework • What do you do? (Cycle 2)

contents.content: Learning objectives:
• reflect on one's learning
• identify areas that need improvement

contents.linkLabel: Classwork • Review lessons 2-5 + Written and Oral Quiz

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to use demonstratives, one, and ones to ask about and describe prices.

contents.linkLabel: Flipped Classroom • How much are these? (Cycle 1)
Classwork • How much are these? (Cycle 1)
Homework • How much are these? (Cycle 1)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to discuss preferences using comparisons with adjectives.

contents.linkLabel: Flipped Classroom • How much are these? (Cycle 2)
Classwork • How much are these? (Cycle 2)
Homework • How much are these? (Cycle 2)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to discuss entertainment likes and dislikes using yes/no and Wh-questions with do.

contents.linkLabel: Flipped Classroom • Do you play the guitar? (Cycle 1)
Classwork • Do you play the guitar? (Cycle 1)
Homework • Do you play the guitar? (Cycle 1)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to make, accept, and decline invitations using would and verb + to + verb.

contents.linkLabel: Flipped Classroom • Do you play the guitar? (Cycle 2)
Classwork • Do you play the guitar? (Cycle 2)
Homework • Do you play the guitar? (Cycle 2)

• reflect on one's learning
• identify areas that need improvement

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to describe families and ask and answer questions using the present continuous.

Classwork • What's an interesting family? (Cycle 1)
Homework • What's an interesting family? (Cycle 1)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to use quantifiers to describe families.

Homework • What's an interesting family? (Cycle 2)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to discuss sports and exercise habits.

Homework • How often do you run? (Cycle 1)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to ask and answer questions about frequency of free-time activities.

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to discuss daily and free-time activities using the <mark>simple past with regular and irregular verbs</mark>.

Classwork • We went dancing! (Cycle 1)
Homework • We went dancing! (Cycle 1)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to discuss vacations using the past tense of be.

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to ask about and describe places using there is/there are and prepositions of place.

Classwork • How's the neighborhood? (Cycle 1)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to describe people’s physical appearance.

contents.linkLabel: Flipped Classroom • What does she look like? (Cycle 1)
Classwork • What does she look like? (Cycle 1)
Homework • What does she look like? (Cycle 1)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to identify people using modifiers with participles and prepositions to describe how they look, what they are wearing, what they’re doing, and where they are.

Classwork • What does she look like? (Cycle 2)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to describe recent activities using the present perfect, already, and yet.

Classwork • Have you ever been there? (Cycle 1)
Homework • Have you ever been there? (Cycle 1)

contents.content: By the end of this lesson, students will be able to describe experiences from the recent and distant past using the present perfect, simple past, for, and since.
